bibl.title: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Frederick F. Russell, June 5, 1929

div1.p: Carter is unable to work on the book until Frost returns from England in August. While he is away, she will try and address loose ends.

div1.head: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Frederick F. Russell, June 5, 1929
div1.opener:
Book, Misel
Report (weekly)
The Westmoreland,
2122 California St., N. W.
Washington, D. C.
June 5, 1929.
Dear Doctor Russell:
div1.p:
A letter from Dr. Frost, recently received, says that
there seems no prospect of his being able to get ahead on the His-
tory of Yellow Fever before sailing for England, on June 22nd. He
adds: “However, I can at least be quite certain of having the neces-
sary time free after August 1st, and I think I can finish promptly
then.” He further states he hopes that I can find it possible to go
over to Baltimore for a day or two before he leaves for England, tak-
ing with me all the material for the book in my possession. This, of
course, I shall do at any time that he sets. In the interim, however,
Dr. Martel (head of the Catalogue Division of the Library of Congress)
and Miss Brown) have promised to spend an evening at my apartment and go
over the library cards with me. This final “survey” should be of
great value as, although we have consulted both Dr. Martel and Dr.
Koënig from time to time about the library cards, it would mean a lot to
turn them over to Dr. Frost with no library technicalities in question.

After I have been to Baltimore, if, as seems probable, there
will be no work for July necessitating my staying in Washington, I think
it would be a very good plan for me to try to spend that month in the
mountains, in Virginia, so as to be in better shape for work with Dr.
Frost in August. During August, and possibly September, I shall proba-
bly have to divide my time between Baltimore and Washington, while Miss
Brown will be needed for the checking of any “loose-ends” at the Library
of Congress. At present, we see no evidence of any “loose-ends,” but I
judge some will materialize during Frost's editing. If Dr. Frost leaves
me any work to do during his absence, I can take my portable typewriter
with me. If it turns out that there is no work to be done during July
July
-2-
I shall, of course, advise you.
div1.closer:
With best wishes, I remain
Very truly yours, Laura A. Carter Dr. Frederick F. Russell,
Director,
International Health Division,
61 Broadway,
New York, N. Y.
P. S. I was so interested to hear from Dr. Barber that he was joining
your outfit in West Africa. I consider both he and the I. H. D. sub-
ject to congratulations thereon.
Miss Brown is about well again and is coming up to-night with the
geographic files.
L.A.C.
